title: Concerns over wildlife and environmental implications of M4 relief road
text:
Leading environmental organisations in Wales have written to First Minister, Carwyn Jones to express their concern about the Welsh Government's proposals for a new M4 relief road.
The project is expected to cost more than £1bn Credit: PA The letter coincides with the start of a series of public exhibitions run by the Welsh Government to allow local residents to share their views about the proposed M4 Black Route, the first of which is held today in Newport.
The letter urges the First Minister to consider the potential environmental implications of the the M4 relief road.
Environmental organisations including Wildlife Trusts Wales and Gwent Wildlife Trust have previously questioned the legality of The Welsh Government's decision to create a new 14 mile stretch of motorway which will cut across the Gwent Levels landscape.
The Welsh Government says the project will boost the economy and ease congestion, and that any environmental impact will be taken into consideration.
Read more about the M4 relief road
Let's not make the challenge of avoiding dangerous climate change even harder with projects that increase our climate change contribution and lock us into carbon intensive activities and infrastructure.
If the Welsh Government is truly committed to promoting sustainable living for future generations, it must be bolder, have a higher level of ambition and look for better, more innovative, twenty-first century solutions to congestion."
– Rachel Sharp, Chief Executive of Wildlife Trusts Wales Last updated Mon 7 Sep 2015 Environment South Wales
